raw_text:
Edwards tips Idowu for Euro gold
 
 World outdoor triple jump record holder and BBC pundit Jonathan Edwards believes Phillips Idowu can take gold at the European Indoor Championships.
 
 Idowu landed 17.30m at the British trials in Sheffield last month to lead the world triple jump rankings. "It's all down to him, but if he jumps as well as he did in Sheffield he could win the gold medal," said Edwards. "His ability is undoubted but all his best performances seem to happen in domestic meetings."
 
 Idowu made his breakthrough five years ago but so far has only a Commonwealth silver medal to his name. Edwards himself kept Idowu off top spot at the Manchester Games. But he believes the European Indoors in Madrid represent a chance for the 26-year-old to prove his credentials as Britain's top triple jumper. "He has to start producing at international level and here is the beginning," said Edwards. "Phillips still needs to be much more consistent. I'm sure a victory in Madrid will build up his confidence and self-belief that he can be best in the world." The qualifying round of the men's triple jump in Madrid takes place on Friday with the final scheduled for Saturday. Olympic champion Christian Olsson will not be taking part as he is out for the entire indoor season with an ankle injury.
llama3.2:1b: Jonathan Edwards believes Phillips Idowu can take gold at the European Indoor Championships, citing his ability and recent performance as Sheffield's 17.30m jump record holder.
llama3.2:3b: Jonathan Edwards believes Phillips Idowu can win gold at the European Indoor Championships, predicting that a good performance in Madrid could boost his confidence and self-belief.
gemma2:2b: Jonathan Edwards believes Phillips Idowu can win gold at the European Indoor Championships. He attributes Idowu's success to his talent but acknowledges the need for consistent international performance.  Iduo needs to build confidence and prove himself as Britain's top triple jumper, according to Edwards.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Edwards praises Jonathan Edwards' prediction that Phillips Idowu can win the gold medal at European Indoor Championships, citing his impressive performance in Sheffield triple jump and his ability to prove himself at the Manchester Games.
To summarize this text concisely:
Jonathan Edwards predicts that Phillips Idowu, who has been a contender for the European Indoor Championships, will be able to secure a gold medal by qualifying in Madrid. He suggests that Idowu must improve his consistency on international levels and believes he can make a stronger start at Madrid than he did at the Manchester Games.
This summary captures the key points of the original text while omitting unnecessary details and not providing an explanation for Edwards' prediction.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Jonathan Edwards believes Phillips Idowu can win gold at the European Indoor Championships, following his impressive performance of 17.30m in Sheffield. Idowu's breakthrough five years ago and recent struggles to secure a top spot have provided opportunity for him to showcase his true abilities, with Edwards stressing the importance of consistency for building confidence towards international success.
qwen2.5:3b: World outdoor triple jump record holder Jonathan Edwards suggests Phillips Idowu can win gold at the European Indoor Championships. Idowu jumped 17.30m in British trials, leading world rankings; Edwards believes he could repeat that performance to claim gold. Despite previous breakthroughs and Commonwealth silver, Idowu needs to prove himself on an international stage. The European Indoors represent a chance for him to do so, with qualifying rounds on Friday and the final scheduled for Saturday. Olympic champion Christian Olsson will not compete due to injury.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this text into a concise summary. Let me read through it carefully.

So, Jonathan Edwards thinks Idowu can win gold in Europe, especially at the indoor triple jump event. He's a former world champion and BBC pundit. Last month, he did well in the British trials but only got second place internationally. He made it to the men's triple jump in Madrid for the World Cup Qualifiers. If he can compete there, he has a chance to prove his talent on an international level.

I should capture who is involved, what he believes, and where they'll be competing from. Also, mention that Olsson isn't participating because of an injury. Let me put this together in my own words without using any markdown or explanations.
</think>

Idowu has been identified as a potential gold contender for Europe's triple jump event, particularly at the European Indoor Championships. Jonathan Edwards believes Idowu can take home gold if he maintains his form and is competitive at the higher level. Last month, Ed walls achieved first place in the UK trials but fell to second place internationally. He advanced to the men's triple jump in Madrid for the World Cup Qualifiers, where he has a chance to prove his talent on an international stage. Christian Olsson, his Olympic rival, will miss the event due to an ankle injury and is not participating.
tinyllama:1.1b: Edwards believes Phillips Idowu has the potential to win gold at the European Indoor Championships, citing his outstanding triple jump performance in Sheffield and the possibility of him reaching his best marks at the championships. The athlete is currently ranked first in world triple jump rankings but has yet to win a major title. Edwards suggests that Idowu's breakthrough five years ago may not have been as impressive if he had competed at the Commonwealth Games, which could be an opportunity for him to prove his credentials. Idowu has yet to reach top form domestically, with his only significant international medal being a silver in the 2016 Commonwealth Games trio jump event. However, with Madrid hosting the European Indoor championships, it presents an excellent opportunity for him to produce at international level and potentially win the gold medal.
